title: Wineries Become ‘Disneyland for Adults’ With Submarines, Climbing Walls
text:
SYDNEY—Winery co-owner Lucy Golding ’s latest investment isn’t more wine barrels or land to expand the vineyards. Instead, it’s a bulbous, 12-foot-tall sphere that resembles a bird’s nest, perched on a hill above her vineyard in southern Australia.

Visitors who book the new “whimsical hand-woven tasting nest,” as Ms. Golding’s website describes it, are treated to a three-hour, multiple-course lunch and wine, plus an expansive view of vineyards and hills in the distance—for the equivalent of $115 per person. Six people can fit comfortably inside, where guests sit on cushions on the floor.

Some customers are “taken aback by the scale of it,” says Ms. Golding, adding that it took her and others about 50 hours to weave willow branches around the steel frame. “This is very much a human-sized nest. It towers over you when you’re in there.”

Even a fancy restaurant or art gallery isn’t always enough to stand out or attract visitors to wineries these days, especially as many younger vacationers seek out increasingly unique experiences. Winemakers, particularly in newer wine-producing countries like Australia and the U.S., are toning down discussions about tannins and terroir—and trying to outdo each other with wine nests, floating golf holes, climbing walls, petting zoos, strange museums and 35-foot-tall rabbit sculptures.

In Europe, some winemakers also offer attractions, but “the bedrock of their success in the wine sector is based on tradition and history,” said Damien Wilson, a professor at Sonoma State University in California and a chair at the school’s Wine Business Institute.

One California winery he recently visited was “almost like Disneyland for adults,” he said.

That winery, Raymond Vineyards in California’s Napa Valley, offers a series of themed rooms including the Corridor of Senses, where visitors squeeze fabric-covered balls on flasks attached to the wall for a whiff of aromas, such as black pepper and honey, that are present in wine. “There’s more of a blank canvas” in the U.S., said Jean-Charles Boisset, a Frenchman who runs the Boisset Collection, which owns the winery. He also oversees wineries in France, where his business opened a tasting lounge in the Burgundian village of Vougeot that sports a “chic and theatrical atmosphere,” its website says.

Raymond Vineyards in California’s Napa Valley offers a series of themed rooms including the Corridor of Senses Photo: Scott Chebegia

The Red Room at Raymond Vineyards in Napa Valley. Photo: Scott Chebegia

In Bordeaux, one of France’s premier wine regions, some wineries offer wine-blending workshops, hot-air balloon and plane rides, walks with donkeys in the vineyard, and yoga, according a list compiled by the Bordeaux Wine Council. A tasting nest didn’t appear on the list—though one winery offered a tasting on a suspended platform in a tree.

Not everyone in this tradition-focused industry, which still debates whether to use corks or screw tops on wine bottles, is fully embracing the idea. Simon Woolf, an English wine writer based in the Netherlands, said he generally prefers a comfortable and quiet space to taste wine, and where he can ideally chat with the winemaker.

“My take would probably be that wineries have to decide if their focus is making the best possible wine, or becoming a tourist attraction,” said Mr. Woolf. “It’s rare for a winery to achieve both, in my experience.”

Share Your Thoughts What’s better? The wine or the experience? Join the conversation below.

To some visitors, the offbeat attractions might initially seem out of place. The 35-foot-tall statue of a leaping rabbit at Hall Wines in Napa Valley seemed unusual to Mr. Wilson, the business professor, given that rabbits can be vineyard pests. Called Bunny Foo Foo, the statue, visible from the highway, is actually a homage to the nursery rhyme that one of the winery owners used to sing with her children.

The Hall Wines Bunny Foo Foo statue in Halloween-themed decor. Photo: HALL Wines

The rabbit has sported illuminated antlers and a nose during Christmas, creating what some employees call Reindeer Foo Foo. When new Star Wars movies were released, a big lightsaber was placed in the front paw of the rabbit, then sometimes called Saber Foo Foo.

“People pull over every day and stop to take pictures of it,” said Mike Reynolds, the president of the winery, which sells some bottles of Cabernet Sauvignon for more than $200. “It’s just fun, and wine is supposed to be fun.”

On San Francisco’s Treasure Island, home to a former naval base, vintner Bryan Kane hosts his tasting room in a former training facility that used to be partially flooded so sailors could practice what to do if a ship were sinking. The interior of the tasting room at Sottomarino Winery—that’s Italian for “submarine”—resembles the inside of a ship, complete with bulkhead doors and portholes.

“People either love or hate the concept,” said Mr. Kane, who makes a Dolcetto that was once judged to be the best in the U.S. at a wine competition sponsored by San Francisco Chronicle. “It’s a historic submarine training unit. We wanted to embrace that.”

Part of the submarine theme at the Sottomarino Winery. Photo: Sottomarino Winery

A party at Sottomarino Winery in San Francisco. Photo: Sottomarino Winery

Others are looking to double down on unusual offerings. In the Australian state of Queensland, which is known for its tropical beaches and rainforests, Cedar Creek Estate Vineyard and Winery built a cave out of concrete about 15 years ago—to house insect larvae that glow in the dark and are known as glow-worms. About half of the visitors to the property go for the glow-worms and don’t even bother with the wine, according to owner John Penglis.

Mr. Penglis next wants to build an aviary so visitors can check out native birds. “I don’t worry what others think,” Mr. Penglis said when asked if more-traditional winemakers snub him.

Back at Golding Wines, one of the first groups to book the wine nest earlier this year included Simon Conn, a 40-year-old academic who lives nearby and says he usually prefers a traditional wine-tasting experience. Still, he enjoyed throwing a football around near the nest and appreciated the personal concierge that looked after his group.

“You don’t make up for a bad winery with some gimmick,” said Mr. Conn, who would visit the tasting nest again and was a fan of the wine. “But you can certainly raise it to another level.”

Write to Mike Cherney at mike.cherney@wsj.com
description: Even a fancy restaurant or art gallery isn’t enough to stand out among wineries these days; ‘almost like Disneyland for adults’
